entities.title: Tang dynasty
entities.description: The Tang dynasty, or Tang Empire, was an imperial dynasty of China that ruled from 618 to 907, with an interregnum between 690 and 705. It was preceded by the Sui dynasty and followed by the Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms period. Historians generally regard the Tang as a high point in Chinese civilization, and a golden age of cosmopolitan culture. Tang territory, acquired through the military cam

heading: Deaths
txt: Guaimar II (Gybbosus), Lombard prince

entities.title: Guaimar II of Salerno
entities.description: Guaimar II was the Lombard prince of Salerno from 901, when his father retired to a monastery, to his death. His father was Guaimar I and his mother was Itta. He was associated with his father in the principality from 893. He was responsible for the rise of the principality: he restored the princely palace, built the palace church of San Pietro a campanile, and restored gold coinage.

heading: Deaths
txt: Muhammad III of Shirvan, Muslim ruler

entities.title: Muhammad III of Shirvan
entities.description: Muhammad III was the third Layzanshah and the seventh Shirvanshah. He was the son of Abu Tahir Yazid.

heading: Deaths
txt: Conrad II, Holy Roman Emperor (b. 990)

entities.title: Conrad II, Holy Roman Emperor
entities.description: Conrad II, also known as Conrad the Elder and Conrad the Salic, was Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire from 1027 until his death in 1039. The first of a succession of four Salian emperors, who reigned for one century until 1125, Conrad also served as King of Germany from 1024, King of Italy from 1026, and King of Burgundy (Arelat) from 1033.

heading: Deaths
txt: Władysław I Herman, Polish nobleman (b. c. 1044)

entities.title: Władysław I Herman
entities.description: Władysław I Herman was the duke of Poland from 1079 until his death.

heading: Deaths
txt: Magnus I of Sweden (b. 1106)

entities.title: Magnus I of Sweden
entities.description: Magnus the Strong was a Danish duke who ruled Gothenland in southern Sweden from the 1120s to c. 1132. It is disputed whether he was elected king by the Swedes, but he is nevertheless sometimes found in the modern list of Swedish monarchs as Magnus I. Snorri Sturlason gives him the epithet Magnus the Strong.

heading: Deaths
txt: Emperor Huizong of Song (b. 1082)

entities.title: Emperor Huizong of Song
entities.description: Emperor Huizong of Song, personal name Zhao Ji, was the eighth emperor of the Song dynasty in China. He was also a very well-known calligrapher. Born as the 11th son of Emperor Shenzong, he ascended the throne in 1100 upon the death of his elder brother and predecessor, Emperor Zhezong, because Emperor Zhezong's only son died prematurely. He lived in luxury, sophistication and art in the first hal

heading: Deaths
txt: Adela of Champagne (b. 1140)

entities.title: Adela of Champagne
entities.description: Adela of Champagne, also known as Adelaide, Alix and Adela of Blois, was Queen of France as the third wife of Louis VII. She was regent of France from 1190 to 1191 while her son Philip II participated in the Third Crusade.

heading: Deaths
txt: Isabella of Angoulême (b. 1188)

entities.title: Isabella of Angoulême
entities.description: Isabella of Angoulême was Queen of England as the second wife of King John from 1200 until John's death in 1216. She was also suo jure Countess of Angoulême from 1202 until 1246.

heading: Deaths
txt: Przemysł I of Greater Poland (b. 1221)

entities.title: Przemysł I of Greater Poland
entities.description: Przemysł I, a member of the Piast dynasty, was Duke of Greater Poland from 1239 until his death, from 1241 with his brother Bolesław the Pious as co-ruler. He was able to re-acquire large parts of Greater Poland, ruling as Duke of Poznań and Gniezno from 1247 and, upon several inheritance conflicts with his brother, as Duke of Poznań and Kalisz from 1249, sole Duke of Greater Poland from 1250, and

heading: Deaths
txt: Mary de Bohun, wife of Henry IV of England (b.c. 1368)

entities.title: Mary de Bohun
entities.description: Mary de Bohun was the first wife of King Henry IV of England and the mother of King Henry V. Mary was never queen, as she died before her husband came to the throne.

entities.title: Henry IV of England
entities.description: Henry IV was King of England from 1399 to 1413. He asserted the claim of his grandfather King Edward III, a maternal grandson of Philip IV of France, to the Kingdom of France. Henry was the first English ruler since the Norman Conquest over three hundred years prior whose mother tongue was English rather than French. He was known as Henry Bolingbroke before ascending to the throne. His father was

heading: Deaths
txt: Andronikos Palaiologos Kantakouzenos, Byzantine commander

entities.title: Andronikos Palaiologos Kantakouzenos
entities.description: Andronikos Palaiologos Kantakouzenos was the last Grand Domestic of the Byzantine Empire. Present in the city at the Fall of Constantinople in 1453, he was one of the group of high Imperial officials executed by Ottoman Sultan Mehmet II five days after the city was taken.

heading: Deaths
txt: Flavio Biondo, Italian historian and author (b. 1392)

entities.title: Flavio Biondo
entities.description:
Flavio Biondo was an Italian Renaissance humanist historian. He was one of the first historians to use a three-period division of history and is known as one of the first archaeologists. 
Born in the capital city of Forlì, in the Romagna region, Flavio was well schooled from an early age, studying under Ballistario of Cremona. During a brief stay in Milan, he discovered and transcribed the unique

heading: Deaths
txt: Nezahualcoyotl, Aztec poet (b. 1402)

entities.title: Nezahualcoyotl (tlatoani)
entities.description: Nezahualcoyotl was a scholar, warrior, architect, poet and ruler (tlatoani) of the city-state of Texcoco in pre-Columbian era Mexico. Unlike other high-profile Mexican figures from the century preceding Spanish conquest of the Aztec Empire, Nezahualcoyotl was not fully Mexica; his father's people were the Acolhua, another Nahuan people settled in the eastern part of the Valley of Mexico, on the co

heading: Deaths
txt: Muretus, French philosopher and author (b. 1526)

entities.title: Muretus
entities.description: Muretus is the Latinized name of Marc Antoine Muret, a French humanist who was among the revivers of a Ciceronian Latin style and is among the usual candidates for the best Latin prose stylist of the Renaissance.

heading: Deaths
txt: Francis Caracciolo, Italian Catholic priest (b. 1563)

entities.title: Francis Caracciolo
entities.description: Francis Caracciolo, born Ascanio Pisquizio, was an Italian Catholic priest who co-founded the Congregation of the Clerics Regular Minor with John Augustine Adorno. He decided to adopt a religious life at the age of 22.

heading: Deaths
txt: Péter Révay, Hungarian soldier and historian (b. 1568)

entities.title: Péter Révay
entities.description:
Baron Péter Révay de Szklabina et Blathnicza was a Hungarian nobleman, Royal Crown Guard for the Holy Crown of Hungary, poet, state official, soldier, and historian. 
He was the grandson of Ferenc Révay.

heading: Deaths
txt: Canonicus, Grand Chief Sachem of the Narragansett (b. 1565)

entities.title: Canonicus
entities.description: Canonicus was a chief of the Narragansett Indian tribe. He was wary of the colonial settlers, but he ultimately proved to be a firm friend of Roger Williams and other settlers.

heading: Deaths
txt: William Juxon, English archbishop and academic (b. 1582)

entities.title: William Juxon
entities.description: William Juxon was an English churchman, Bishop of London from 1633 to 1646 and Archbishop of Canterbury from 1660 until his death.

heading: Deaths
txt: Giacomo Casanova, Italian adventurer and author (b. 1725)

entities.title: Giacomo Casanova
entities.description: Giacomo Girolamo Casanova was an Italian adventurer and author from the Republic of Venice. His autobiography, Histoire de ma vie, is regarded as one of the most authentic sources of the customs and norms of European social life during the 18th century.

heading: Deaths
txt: Frederick Muhlenberg, American minister and politician, 1st Speaker of the United States House of Representatives (b. 1750)

entities.title: Frederick Muhlenberg
entities.description: Frederick Augustus Conrad Muhlenberg was an American minister and politician who was the first Speaker of the United States House of Representatives. A delegate to the Pennsylvania state constitutional convention and a member of the U.S. House of Representatives from Pennsylvania and a Lutheran pastor by profession, Muhlenberg was born in Trappe, Pennsylvania. His home, known as The Speaker's Hous

entities.title: Speaker of the United States House of Representatives
entities.description: The speaker of the United States House of Representatives, commonly known as the Speaker of the House, is the presiding officer of the United States House of Representatives. The office was established in 1789 by Article I, Section 2 of the U.S. Constitution. The speaker is the political and parliamentary leader of the House of Representatives and is simultaneously the House's presiding officer, d

heading: Deaths
txt: Nicolai Abildgaard, Danish neoclassical and history painter, sculptor and architect (b. 1743)

entities.title: Nicolai Abildgaard
entities.description: Nicolai Abraham Abildgaard was a Danish neoclassical and royal history painter, sculptor, architect, and professor of painting, mythology, and anatomy at the New Royal Danish Academy of Art in Copenhagen, Denmark. Many of his works were in the royal Christiansborg Palace, Fredensborg Palace, and Levetzau Palace at Amalienborg.

heading: Deaths
txt: Antonio José de Sucre, Venezuelan general and politician, 2nd President of Bolivia (b. 1795)

entities.title: Antonio José de Sucre
entities.description: Antonio José de Sucre y Alcalá, known as "Gran Mariscal de Ayacucho", was a Venezuelan independence leader who served as the 4th President of Peru and as the 2nd President of Bolivia. Sucre was one of Simón Bolívar's closest friends, generals and statesmen.

entities.title: President of Bolivia
entities.description: The President of Bolivia, officially known as the President of the Plurinational State of Bolivia, is head of state and head of government of Bolivia and the Captain General of the Armed Forces of Bolivia.

heading: Deaths
txt: Johan Rudolph Thorbecke, Dutch historian, jurist, and politician, Prime Minister of the Netherlands (b. 1798)

entities.title: Johan Rudolph Thorbecke
entities.description: Johan Rudolph Thorbecke was a Dutch liberal statesman, one of the most important Dutch politicians of the 19th century. In 1848, he virtually single-handedly drafted the revision of the Constitution of the Netherlands, giving less power to the king and more to the States General, and guaranteeing more religious, personal and political freedom to the people.

entities.title: Prime Minister of the Netherlands
entities.description: The prime minister of the Netherlands is the head of the executive branch of the Government of the Netherlands. The prime minister is the chair of the Council of Ministers and coordinates its policy with his cabinet. The current acting prime minister is Mark Rutte, who serves in a demissionary capacity after his resignation on 15 January 2021.

heading: Deaths
txt: Eduard Mörike, German pastor and poet (b. 1804)

entities.title: Eduard Mörike
entities.description: Eduard Friedrich Mörike was a German Lutheran pastor who was also a Romantic poet and writer of novellas and novels. Many of his poems were set to music and became established folk songs, while others were used by composers Hugo Wolf and Ignaz Lachner in their symphonic works.

heading: Deaths
txt: Abdülaziz of the Ottoman Empire, 32nd Sultan of the Ottoman Empire (b. 1830)

entities.title: Abdülaziz of the Ottoman Empire
entities.description: Abdulaziz was the 32nd Sultan of the Ottoman Empire and reigned between 25 June 1861 and 30 May 1876. He was the son of Sultan Mahmud II and succeeded his brother Abdulmejid I in 1861.

heading: Deaths
txt: W. H. R. Rivers, English anthropologist, neurologist, ethnologist, and psychiatrist (b. 1864)

entities.title: W. H. R. Rivers
entities.description: William Halse Rivers Rivers was an English anthropologist, neurologist, ethnologist and psychiatrist, best known for his work treating First World War officers who were suffering from shell shock in order to return them to combat. Rivers' most famous patient was the poet Siegfried Sassoon, with whom he remained close friends until his own sudden death.

heading: Deaths
txt: Margaret Murray Washington, American Academic (b. 1865)

entities.title: Margaret Murray Washington
entities.description: Margaret Murray Washington was an American educator who was the principal of Tuskegee Normal and Industrial Institute, which later became Tuskegee University. She was the third wife of Booker T. Washington. She was inducted into the Alabama Women's Hall of Fame in 1972.

heading: Deaths
txt: Fred Spofforth, Australian-English cricketer and coach (b. 1853)

entities.title: Fred Spofforth
entities.description: Frederick Robert Spofforth, also known as "The Demon Bowler", was arguably the Australian cricket team's finest pace bowler of the nineteenth century. He was the first bowler to take 50 Test wickets, and the first to take a Test hat-trick, in 1879. He played in Test matches for Australia between 1877 and 1887, and then settled in England where he played for Derbyshire. In 2011, he was inducted int

heading: Deaths
txt: Zhang Zuolin, Chinese warlord (b. 1873)

entities.title: Zhang Zuolin
entities.description: Zhang Zuolin was an influential Chinese bandit, soldier, and warlord during the Warlord Era in China. The warlord of Manchuria from 1916 to 1928, and the military dictator of the Republic of China in 1927 and 1928, he rose from banditry to power and influence.

heading: Deaths
txt: Harry Frazee, American director, producer, and agent (b. 1881)

entities.title: Harry Frazee
entities.description: Harry Herbert Frazee was an American theatrical agent, producer and director, and owner of the Major League Baseball Boston Red Sox from 1916 to 1923. He is well known for selling Babe Ruth to the New York Yankees, which started the Curse of the Bambino.

heading: Deaths
txt: Hussein bin Ali, Sharif of Mecca, Sharif and Emir of Mecca, King of the Hejaz (b. 1853/54)

entities.title: Hussein bin Ali, Sharif of Mecca
entities.description: Hussein bin Ali Al-Hashimi was an Arab leader from the Banu Hashim clan who was the Sharif and Emir of Mecca from 1908 and, after proclaiming the Great Arab Revolt against the Ottoman Empire, King of the Hejaz from 1916 to 1924. At the end of his reign he also briefly laid claim to the office of Caliph. He was a 37th-generation direct descendant of Muhammad, as he belongs to the Hashemite family.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ahmet Haşim, Turkish poet and author (b. 1884)

entities.title: Ahmet Haşim
entities.description: Ahmet Haşim was an influential Turkish poet of the early 20th century.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mathilde Verne, English pianist and educator (b. 1869)

entities.title: Mathilde Verne
entities.description: Mathilde Verne was an English pianist and teacher, of German descent. Along with most of her other sisters, Mathilde changed her surname to Verne in 1893 after the death of their father, John Wurm.

heading: Deaths
txt: Tommy Ladnier, American trumpet player (b. 1900)

entities.title: Tommy Ladnier
entities.description: Thomas James Ladnier was an American jazz trumpeter. Hugues Panassié – an influential French critic, jazz historian, and renowned exponent of New Orleans jazz – rated Ladnier, sometime on or before 1956, second only to Louis Armstrong.

heading: Deaths
txt: Wilhelm II, German Emperor (b. 1859)

entities.title: Wilhelm II, German Emperor
entities.description: Wilhelm II, anglicised as William II, was the last German Emperor (Kaiser) and King of Prussia, reigning from 15 June 1888 until his abdication on 9 November 1918. Despite strengthening Germany's position as a great power by building a blue-water navy and promoting scientific innovation, his tactless public statements greatly antagonized the international community and his foreign policy was seen

heading: Deaths
txt: Reinhard Heydrich, German SS officer and politician (b. 1904)

entities.title: Reinhard Heydrich
entities.description: Reinhard Tristan Eugen Heydrich was a high-ranking German SS and police official during the Nazi era and a principal architect of the Holocaust. He was chief of the Reich Main Security Office. He was also Stellvertretender Reichsprotektor of Bohemia and Moravia. He served as president of the International Criminal Police Commission and chaired the January 1942 Wannsee Conference which formalised p

entities.title: SS
entities.description: The Schutzstaffel was a major paramilitary organization under Adolf Hitler and the Nazi Party in Nazi Germany, and later throughout German-occupied Europe during World War II. It began with a small guard unit known as the Saal-Schutz made up of party volunteers to provide security for party meetings in Munich. In 1925, Heinrich Himmler joined the unit, which had by then been reformed and given its

heading: Deaths
txt: Serge Koussevitzky, Russian-American bassist, composer, and conductor (b. 1874)

entities.title: Serge Koussevitzky
entities.description: Serge Alexandrovich Koussevitzky was a Russian-born conductor, composer and double-bassist, known for his long tenure as music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra from 1924 to 1949.

heading: Deaths
txt: Katherine MacDonald, American actress and producer (b. 1881)

entities.title: Katherine MacDonald
entities.description: Katherine Agnew MacDonald was an American stage and film actress, film producer, and model. She was born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania and was the older sister of actresses Miriam MacDonald and Mary MacLaren.

heading: Deaths
txt: Clem McCarthy, American sportscaster (b. 1882)

entities.title: Clem McCarthy
entities.description: Clem McCarthy was an American sportscaster and public address announcer. He also lent his voice to Pathe News's RKO newsreels. He was known for his gravelly voice and dramatic style, a "whiskey tenor" as sports announcer and executive David J. Halberstam has called it.

heading: Deaths
txt: Linda Eenpalu, Estonian lawyer and politician (b. 1890)

entities.title: Linda Eenpalu
entities.description: Linda Marie Eenpalu was an Estonian politician. She was a member of the National Constituent Assembly (1937) and a Member of the Second Chamber of the National Council (1938) and the first of her gender in both of these positions. She was a well-known women's rights activist. She was married to politician Kaarel Eenpalu, who was prime minister in 1938–39.

heading: Deaths
txt: Dorothy Gish, American actress (b. 1898)

entities.title: Dorothy Gish
entities.description: Dorothy Elizabeth Gish was an American actress of the screen and stage, as well as a director and writer. Dorothy and her older sister Lillian Gish were major movie stars of the silent era. Dorothy also had great success on the stage, and was inducted into the American Theater Hall of Fame. Dorothy Gish was noted as a fine comedian, and many of her films were comedies.

heading: Deaths
txt: Sonny Tufts, American actor (b. 1911)

entities.title: Sonny Tufts
entities.description: Bowen Charlton "Sonny" Tufts III was an American stage, film, and television actor. He is best known for the films he made as a contract star at Paramount in the 1940s, including So Proudly We Hail!. He also starred in the cult classic Cat-Women of the Moon.

heading: Deaths
txt: György Lukács, Hungarian historian and philosopher (b. 1885)

entities.title: György Lukács
entities.description: György Lukács was a Hungarian Marxist philosopher, literary historian, critic, and aesthetician of Jewish heritage. He was one of the founders of Western Marxism, an interpretive tradition that departed from the Marxist ideological orthodoxy of the Soviet Union. He developed the theory of reification, and contributed to Marxist theory with developments of Karl Marx's theory of class consciousness.

heading: Deaths
txt: Maurice René Fréchet, French mathematician and academic (b. 1878)

entities.title: Maurice René Fréchet
entities.description: Maurice René Fréchet was a French mathematician. He made major contributions to the topology of point sets and introduced the entire concept of metric spaces. He also made several important contributions to the field of statistics and probability, as well as calculus. His dissertation opened the entire field of functionals on metric spaces and introduced the notion of compactness. Independently of

heading: Deaths
txt: Murry Wilson, American songwriter, producer, and manager (b. 1917)

heading: Deaths
txt: Leslie Averill, New Zealand doctor and soldier (b. 1897)

entities.title: Leslie Averill
entities.description: Leslie Cecil Lloyd Averill was a New Zealand soldier who served during the First World War on the Western Front. After the war, he became a doctor and established a private practice in his hometown of Christchurch. He also served as a medical administrator and community leader.

heading: Deaths
txt: Dik Browne, American cartoonist (b. 1917)

entities.title: Dik Browne
entities.description: Dik Browne, born Richard Arthur Allan Browne in New York City, was an American cartoonist, best known for writing and drawing Hägar the Horrible and Hi and Lois.

heading: Deaths
txt: Stiv Bators, American singer-songwriter and guitarist (b. 1949)

entities.title: Stiv Bators
entities.description: Steven John Bator, known professionally as Stiv Bators, was an American punk rock vocalist and guitarist from Girard, Ohio. He is best remembered for his bands Dead Boys and The Lords of the New Church.

heading: Deaths
txt: Carl Stotz, American businessman, founded Little League Baseball (b. 1910)

entities.title: Carl Stotz
entities.description: Carl E. Stotz was the American founder of Little League Baseball. Stotz was born in Williamsport, Pennsylvania.

entities.title: Little League Baseball
entities.description: Little League Baseball and Softball is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization based in South Williamsport, Pennsylvania, United States, that organizes local youth baseball and softball leagues throughout the United States and the rest of the world.

heading: Deaths
txt: Bernard Evslin, American writer (b. 1922)

entities.title: Bernard Evslin
entities.description: Bernard Evslin was an American author best known for his adaptations of Greek mythology.

heading: Deaths
txt: Derek Leckenby, English musician (b. 1943)

entities.title: Derek Leckenby
entities.description: Derek "Lek" Leckenby was an English musician and lead guitarist, most famous for his work with English pop group Herman's Hermits.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ronnie Lane, English singer-songwriter, guitarist, and producer (b. 1946)

entities.title: Ronnie Lane
entities.description: Ronald Frederick Lane was an English musician, songwriter, and producer who is best known as the bass guitarist and founding member of two prominent English rock and roll bands: Small Faces (1965–69) and subsequently Faces (1969–73). With Small Faces he was nicknamed "Plonk". After their breakup and re-formation as Faces, he acquired the nickname "Three-Piece".

heading: Deaths
txt: Josephine Hutchinson, American actress (b. 1903)

entities.title: Josephine Hutchinson
entities.description: Josephine Hutchinson was an American actress. She acted in several theater plays and films.

heading: Deaths
txt: Fernando Belaúnde Terry, Peruvian architect and politician, 42nd President of Peru (b. 1912)

entities.title: Fernando Belaúnde Terry
entities.description: Fernando Belaúnde Terry was a Peruvian politician who twice served as President of Peru. Deposed by a military coup in 1968, he was re-elected in 1980 after twelve years of military rule.

entities.title: President of Peru
entities.description: The president of Peru, formally recognized as the President of the Republic of Peru, is the head of state and head of government of Peru. The president is the head of the executive branch and is the Supreme Head of the Armed Forces and Police of Peru. The office of president corresponds to the highest magistracy in the country, making the president the highest ranking public official in Peru.

heading: Deaths
txt: Steve Lacy, American saxophonist and composer (b. 1934)

entities.title: Steve Lacy (saxophonist)
entities.description: Steve Lacy, born Steven Norman Lackritz in New York City, was an American jazz saxophonist and composer recognized as one of the important players of soprano saxophone. Coming to prominence in the 1950s as a progressive dixieland musician, Lacy went on to a long and prolific career. He worked extensively in experimental jazz and to a lesser extent in free improvisation, but Lacy's music was typica

heading: Deaths
txt: Nino Manfredi, Italian actor (b. 1921)

heading: Deaths
txt: Clete Boyer, American baseball player and manager (b. 1937)

entities.title: Clete Boyer
entities.description: Cletis Leroy "Clete" Boyer was an American professional baseball third baseman — who occasionally played shortstop and second base — in Major League Baseball (MLB) for the Kansas City Athletics (1955–57), New York Yankees (1959–66), and Atlanta Braves (1967–71). Boyer also spent four seasons with the Taiyō Whales of Nippon Professional Baseball (NPB). In his 16-year big league career, Boyer hit 16

heading: Deaths
txt: Bill France, Jr., American businessman (b. 1933)

heading: Deaths
txt: Craig L. Thomas, American captain and politician (b. 1933)

heading: Deaths
txt: John Wooden, American basketball player and coach (b. 1910)

entities.title: John Wooden
entities.description: John Robert Wooden was an American basketball player and coach. Nicknamed the "Wizard of Westwood," he won ten National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) national championships in a 12-year period as head coach for the UCLA Bruins, including a record seven in a row. No other team has won more than four in a row in Division I college men's or women's basketball. Within this period, his teams w

heading: Deaths
txt: Juan Francisco Luis, Virgin Islander sergeant and politician, 23rd Governor of the United States Virgin Islands (b. 1940)

entities.title: Juan Francisco Luis
entities.description: Juan Francisco Luis was a Puerto Rican politician in the United States Virgin Islands who served as the third elected Governor of the U.S. Virgin Islands. He is the territory's 23rd governor overall. Luis assumed the governorship on January 2, 1978, succeeding Governor Cyril King, who died in office. He held the governor's office from 1978 until 1987, becoming the longest-serving governor in the h

entities.title: Governor of the United States Virgin Islands
entities.description: The governor of the United States Virgin Islands is the chief executive of the Government of the Virgin Islands whose responsibilities also include making the annual State of the Territory addresses to the Virgin Islands Legislature, submitting the budget, and ensuring that territory public laws are enforced. The position was created through the passage of the Elective Governor Acts of 1968 which

heading: Deaths
txt: Andreas P. Nielsen, Danish author and composer (b. 1953)

heading: Deaths
txt: Peter Beaven, New Zealand architect, designed the Lyttelton Road Tunnel Administration Building (b. 1925)

entities.title: Peter Beaven
entities.description: Peter Jamieson Beaven was a New Zealand architect based in Christchurch, who lived for his last few months in Blenheim. He was a co-founder of New Zealand's first heritage lobby group, the Civic Trust.

entities.title: Lyttelton Road Tunnel Administration Building
entities.description: The Lyttelton Road Tunnel Administration Building was built in the mid-1960s as an operational building for the Lyttelton road tunnel in Christchurch, New Zealand. The building was designed by architect Peter Beaven and is seen as significant in the development of New Zealand architecture.

heading: Deaths
txt: Pedro Borbón, Dominican-American baseball player (b. 1946)

heading: Deaths
txt: Rodolfo Quezada Toruño, Guatemalan cardinal (b. 1932)

heading: Deaths
txt: Herb Reed, American violinist (b. 1929)

heading: Deaths
txt: Walt Arfons, American race car driver (b. 1916)

entities.title: Walt Arfons
entities.description: Walter Charles "Walt" (Poppy) Arfons was the half brother of Art Arfons, his former partner in drag racing, and his competitor in jet-powered land speed record racing. Along with Art, he was a pioneer in the use of aircraft jet engines for these types of competition.

heading: Deaths
txt: Joey Covington, American drummer (b. 1945)

heading: Deaths
txt: Hermann Gunnarsson, Icelandic footballer, handball player, and sportscaster (b. 1946)

heading: Deaths
txt: Will Wynn, American football player (b. 1949)

heading: Deaths
txt: George Ho, American-Hong Kong businessman (b. 1919)

entities.title: George Ho
entities.description: George Ho Cho-chi, GBS, OBE, JP was a Hong Kong media mogul. The fifth son of the influential businessman Robert Hotung, George Ho was the founder of the Commercial Radio Hong Kong and Commercial Television.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nathan Shamuyarira, Zimbabwean journalist and politician, Zimbabwean Minister of Foreign Affairs (b. 1928)

entities.title: Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Zimbabwe)
entities.description: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Zimbabwe is a cabinet ministry of Zimbabwe, responsible for conducting foreign relations of the country.

heading: Deaths
txt: Sydney Templeman, Baron Templeman, English lawyer and judge (b. 1920)

heading: Deaths
txt: Don Zimmer, American baseball player, coach, and manager (b. 1931)

heading: Deaths
txt: Marguerite Patten, English economist and author (b. 1915)

entities.title: Marguerite Patten
entities.description: Hilda Elsie Marguerite Patten,, was an English home economist, food writer and broadcaster. She was one of the earliest celebrity chefs who became known during World War II thanks to her programme on BBC Radio, where she shared recipes that could work within the limits imposed by war rationing. After the war, she was responsible for popularising the use of pressure cookers and her 170 published bo

heading: Deaths
txt: Leonid Plyushch, Ukrainian mathematician and academic (b. 1938)

heading: Deaths
txt: Jabe Thomas, American race car driver (b. 1930)

heading: Deaths
txt: Anne Warburton, British academic and diplomat, British Ambassador to Denmark (b. 1927)

entities.title: List of Ambassadors of the United Kingdom to Denmark
entities.description: The Ambassador of the United Kingdom to Denmark is the United Kingdom's foremost diplomatic representative in Denmark, and head of the UK's diplomatic mission in Denmark. The official title is Her Britannic Majesty's Ambassador to the Kingdom of Denmark.

heading: Deaths
txt: Carmen Pereira, Bissau-Guinean politician (b. 1937)

entities.title: Carmen Pereira
entities.description: Carmen Maria de Araújo Pereira was a Bissau-Guinean politician. She served three days as Acting President in 1984, becoming the first woman in this role in Africa and the only one in Guinea-Bissau's history. She had the shortest term as the Acting President, serving only three days in office. She died in Bissau on 4 June 2016.

heading: Deaths
txt: Juan Goytisolo, Spanish essayist, poet and novelist (b. 1931)

entities.title: Juan Goytisolo
entities.description:
Juan Goytisolo Gay was a Spanish poet, essayist, and novelist. He lived in Marrakesh from 1997 until his death in 2017.
He was considered Spain's greatest living writer at the beginning of the 21st century, yet he had lived abroad since the 1950s.
On 24 November 2014 he was awarded the Cervantes Prize, the most prestigious literary award in the Spanish-speaking world.
